David Muncher has a fantastic history shrouded in mystery, suspense and a l=
ittle bit of folklore. =C2=A0
No seriously though, up until about 2004 this=
 was I believe the only known release of this program, until I purchased a =
collection from a former Bally employee and came across two carts both with=
 the name "Munchie" on the title menu.=C2=A0
Both carts play the same and s=
eem complete, but whether they are prototypes or just complete, unreleased =
games I cannot say.=C2=A0
After a little digging on my part, some posts on =
this group, it turns out "Munchie" was in fact the name of the Pac-Man game=
 Astrocade was going to release, its even advertised in a commercial:
Astro=
vision's Astro Professional Arcade commercial #2


  
|  
|   
|   
|   |  =
  |

   |

  |
|  
|    |  
Astrovision's Astro Professional Arcade commerc=
ial #2
 Astro Arcade, The Professional Videogame System that gives you four=
-player capability, three built-in games, a c...  |   |

  |

  |

 
(Altho=
ugh at the time they were in transition and still going with the "Astro Arc=
ade" console name).=C2=A0

One of the software catalogs has it listed as we=
ll:
http://www.ballyalley.com/ads_and_catalogs/bally/BPA_Catalog_(With_9_Ga=
mes).pdf
Now how Pac-Man became Munchie and after the Atari lawsuit got "le=
aked" out and renamed and released as "Muncher" would be a great story unto=
 itself (if it even happened that way or in that order).
I'm thinking we ha=
ve the makings here for a future episode of the Bally Alley Astrocast:
"Fro=
m Pac-Man to Munchie to Muncher: the untold story of how this maze game mad=
e it onto the Astrocade"
-Michael=C2=A0

      From: "David Dibbern daviddi=
bbern@... [ballyalley]" <ballyalley@yahoogroups.com>
 To: ballyalley@=
yahoogroups.com 
 Sent: Monday, November 21, 2016 11:22 PM
 Subject: Re: [b=
allyalley] High Score Club, Round 13 - Blast Droids and Haunted House
   
=
=C2=A0   Wasn't muncher a astrocade non release or limited release? I have =
both Galaxian and space invaders labeled as such when they had the real arc=
ade names . Back in des plaines , Ill there was a place that rented Atari, =
coleco, oddesy and astrocade , and ever channel F. Game carts. video juncti=
on and they rented tapes as well. The best was they bought carts as well an=
d those are the ones they rented out . They even rented apple II 5.25 disks=
 ( we had locksmith back then) 

There are l

> On Nov 21, 2016, at 8:12 PM=
, Michael Di Salvo msdconsulting@... [ballyalley] <ballyalley@yahoogr=
oups.com> wrote:
> 
> Stores that rented Atari consoles and games were quit=
e rare in the early 80s (or, anytime, really). So, let me get this right...=
 there was a store near you that rented Astrocade systems and games? This i=
s the first I've ever heard of this. Where was it located?

      <div id=3D"yui_3_16_0_1_1479849675976_5251">Wasn't muncher a ast=
rocade non release or limited release?  I have both Galaxian and space inva=
ders labeled as such when they had the real arcade names . Back in des plai=
nes , Ill there was a place that rented Atari, coleco, oddesy and astrocade=
 , and ever channel F. Game carts. video junction and they rented tapes as =
well.  The best was they bought carts as well and those are the ones they r=
ented out . They even rented apple II 5.25 disks ( we had locksmith back th=
en)   <br clear=3D"none">
<br clear=3D"none">
There are l<br clear=3D"none"=
>
<br clear=3D"none">
> On Nov 21, 2016, at 8:12 PM, Michael Di Salvo ms=
dconsulting@... [ballyalley] <ballyalley@yahoogroups.com> wrote=
:<br clear=3D"none">
> <br clear=3D"none">
> Stores that rented Atari=
 consoles and games were quite rare in the early 80s (or, anytime, really).=
  So, let me get this right... there was a store near you that rented Astro=
cade systems and games?  This is the first I've ever heard of this.  Where =
was it located?<br clear=3D"none">
</div>
